data.text: Press release: Monetary policy decisions https://t.co/UBvkhSCGr7
Later today: watch live as ECB President Christine @Lagarde explains the latest monetary policy decisions. https://t.co/zGh98awhBJ

Register now and watch live from 15:30 CET: Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria takes part in the @BancoDeEspana round table “The future is here: challenges in the banking business models” https://t.co/iDfbxXPuBM https://t.co/BBH4Ultmox

It’s possible for banks to provide good customer service while improving cost efficiency by closing branches and enhancing digitalisation, says Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria. Digitalisation frees up resources to help those who are less tech-savvy https://t.co/F3iTUsNjnO https://t.co/vzKsMqgWme

Connecting with the people we serve is important to us. We want to keep the dialogue open. Our ECB & You initiative helps people put their questions directly to President @Lagarde.

Check out the webpage to find out more https://t.co/BtoIHWdXrU https://t.co/QWUTgkm00L

The Memorial at the Frankfurt Grossmarkthalle at the ECB’s main building opens again in June. Over 10,000 members of Frankfurt’s Jewish population were deported from here to concentration camps between 1941 and 1945. #WeRemember 

To visit, see https://t.co/PW6kmnWeI0 https://t.co/F7s5SoWmhs
Euro area bank interest rate statistics (April 2022) https://t.co/WQ6lLnD8sV

Croatia’s progress demonstrates its commitment to adopting the euro, says Executive Board member Fabio Panetta at the @Europarl_EN.
It is another step towards economic and monetary integration, underpinning our collective economic strength and sovereignty 
https://t.co/nT3jZ44SVm https://t.co/1FuUd0PIdI

Croatia could become the euro area’s 20th member from next year, our assessment finds.

This shows that the single currency and economic and monetary integration in Europe remain attractive goals.

Watch the video message by Chief Economist Philip R. Lane ⬇️ https://t.co/jfMFPnytI8

Croatia fulfils all criteria for euro adoption as of 2023, our latest Convergence Report shows.

Other non-euro area EU countries have made limited progress in meeting the requirements to join the euro area, mainly due to challenging economic conditions https://t.co/aIc4h4hpxi https://t.co/9e1gHiWihu

Live at 17:15 CET: Executive Board member Fabio Panetta and European Commission Executive Vice-President @VDombrovskis discuss the ECB’s and Commission’s latest convergence reports in a meeting of the Euro Accession Countries Working Group.

Follow here https://t.co/ufemJc2fkQ
Working Paper: Temporal networks in the analysis of financial contagion https://t.co/htAoQwcjMU

The total value of assets held by euro area insures fell by €329 billion over the first quarter of 2022. This is the largest quarterly decline since the start of 2020. A fall in the value of bond holdings was the main cause. 

Read our press release https://t.co/33eYT6RXZF https://t.co/SGi9LaqBBE

Firms also anticipate the continuation of upward pressures on selling prices in the coming months, due to high inflation expectations as well as higher input prices. Expectations for future turnover remain positive.

Take a look at the results https://t.co/DoCGWCWccf

3/3

Although the availability of external funding was broadly in line with financing demands, firms reported a tightening of financing conditions and the expectation that the availability of funding will deteriorate

2/3

🧵 Our latest survey on the access to finance of enterprises shows business activity continued to recover between October 2021 and March 2022, despite the impact of the war in Ukraine and surging input costs https://t.co/FFiwTtaUGA

1/3 https://t.co/r9EXeODT3L
Euro area insurance corporation statistics (Q1 2022) https://t.co/33eYT6RXZF

How has financial stability been doing since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine? What risks are we keeping an eye on, for instance in the crypto-asset and housing markets? 
Tune in to #TheECBPodcast with experts Tamarah Shakir, @JohnPCFell and host @KatieRanger_ https://t.co/gAzz8yN80s https://t.co/NbwagSz04z

Common standards are needed to reassure investors that green bonds can finance the transition to a low-carbon economy effectively. 

Read more in our Financial Stability Review https://t.co/2osERx9L7k 2/2

🧵 Credibility counts!

Green finance is growing. But only the most credible green bonds seem to benefit from cheaper funding, trading at a “greenium” – a green premium – with lower yields than conventional bonds 1/2 https://t.co/XdM6Z12NDP
Working Paper: One scheme fits all - A central fiscal capacity for the EMU targeting eurozone, national and regional shocks https://t.co/dPBxIMR413

Firms face new challenges as costs soar and the growth outlook weakens. The number of firms that might default is rising. Those hit hard during the pandemic are particularly exposed to higher energy prices.

Read more in our Financial Stability Review https://t.co/FDSHDDxzB2 https://t.co/5IOXqwB2f4

Lane: It’s too early to know what will happen after September. It depends on how the economy evolves. Our policy roadmap covers different views – on one side, that inflation is exclusively due to a supply shock and, on the other, that there is a big domestic demand component

2/2

🧵 It’s important to set clear expectations, given the uncertainty we face, Chief Economist Philip R. Lane tells @CincoDiascom. Our roadmap for monetary policy includes ending net asset purchases in July and the end of negative rates in September https://t.co/u9Ztmk5gNJ

1/2 https://t.co/cdq0Ef8iI9

We recently published our latest Financial Stability Review, but what does financial stability mean in practice? How do we help monitor and stave off potential risks in the financial system? 

Read our explainer to find out https://t.co/rzwQ6P2oIS https://t.co/guDh0LdPZm

With our explainers we want to open central banking themes up for everyone. The simple texts, videos and infographics answer questions about topics such as monetary policy, price stability and financial stability.
Check them out 
https://t.co/tGZhpKpifu
How did euro area bank lending and money supply evolve in April? How do they compare with March's figures? Find out more in the press release https://t.co/XV1sFf5t7z https://t.co/fDcniaqVLr

Exposure of European banks to Russian counterparts is a manageable challenge, says Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria. It is second-round effects that matter most, such as a slowdown of growth in the euro area, and rising energy and commodity prices https://t.co/WlEU6bSwcK https://t.co/nUTDKNlNNh

🗓 There is one week left to apply for the ECB Scholarship for Women!

The programme is open to women doing a master’s degree in economics, statistics, engineering or computing and offers grants of €10,000.

Apply by 1 June https://t.co/U0JWSmHU8b https://t.co/nP2Yc7PlHf

The outlook for financial stability has weakened as higher inflation and Russia’s war in Ukraine test the strength of the recovery after the pandemic, our latest Financial Stability Review shows.

Read more https://t.co/7p77dPHwTC https://t.co/lIyzPTPbrj

Live today at 11:45 CET: Chief Economist Philip R. Lane discusses challenges for monetary policy in times of crisis. He will speak at a conference marking the 20th anniversary of the @bernacerprize  https://t.co/yzymCA7XLP https://t.co/G9tH2DwVIo

Panetta: A critical element in determining the normalisation process will be how rate increases are transmitted. 
Addressing fragmentation risks is central to the normal conduct of monetary policy in the euro area. We should avoid the risk of a “normalisation tantrum”.
 
4/4

Panetta: Subject to incoming data, ending net asset purchases and then gradually exiting negative rates would allow us to remove the part of our monetary accommodation that is no longer needed, while continuing to steer output back towards potential
 
3/4

Panetta: We are normalising monetary policy in times that are anything but normal. 
Confronted with negative supply shocks and a lack of excess domestic demand, we should adjust our policy gradually and choose a mix of instruments that is robust to the uncertainty we face
 
2/4

🧵 Normalisation does not mean removing stimulus outright, says Executive Board member Fabio Panetta. It's a process of gradually reducing that stimulus in a way that firmly anchors the inflation path at 2% over the medium term
 
https://t.co/kVmQrv5xzr
 
1/4 https://t.co/K9gnHRyfMy
Results of the March 2022 survey on credit terms and conditions in euro-denominated securities financing and over-the-counter derivatives markets (SESFOD) https://t.co/C9twqqu7RP

Securitisations of non-performing assets reached a record high in 2021. We monitor transactions to ensure that they are robustly structured, limiting potential danger to the banks. Read more in the Supervision Newsletter https://t.co/f8jI9lQmc8 https://t.co/HqdYV9sW5E

Crypto-assets are highly risky.

Yet interest in them has grown, with connections with the finance industry increasing. If this continues, crypto-assets will pose a risk to financial stability. 

Read why in a preview of our Financial Stability Review https://t.co/rsXBfRdkRN https://t.co/TER0hr2hWp

McCaul/Fernandez-Bollo: Anti-money laundering authorities and banking supervisors need to work closely with one another. With legislators setting up a new European framework, we now have a unique opportunity to boost much-needed collaboration 

2/2

🧵 Money laundering and terrorist financing issues pose a serious challenge to the sound management of banks, say Supervisory Board members Elizabeth McCaul and Edouard Fernandez-Bollo in their joint contribution to The Supervision Blog https://t.co/SiyduCGods

1/2 https://t.co/TSruKiKliC

Financial markets are becoming more aware of climate-related risks as firms get better at disclosing their exposures, our latest Financial Stability Review finds. But the risk of greenwashing is still a concern, one which may be increasing. Read more https://t.co/IVQJZ5MTZb https://t.co/NNByvRohoz

We looked at 99 banks and found that 70% of them must exchange initial margin for over-the-counter derivative trading by September 2022. We will work with them to make the process prudent, efficient and transparent. Read more in the Supervision Newsletter https://t.co/f8jI9lQmc8 https://t.co/hHfnu9O20Q

Smaller banks face issues that are similar to but more pronounced than those of their larger peers: boards are not diverse enough and have too few independent board members. 

Read about this and more in the Supervision Newsletter https://t.co/f8jI9lQmc8 https://t.co/WxWfqiMOVF

Banks generally have enough capital to weather the immediate effects of the war in Ukraine, but some are vulnerable if their specific economic circumstances change for the worse. Read about this and more in the Supervision Newsletter https://t.co/f8jI9lQmc8 https://t.co/gS1yyVsyyM
Working Paper: The double materiality of climate physical and transition risks in the euro area https://t.co/GB66QoT1IF

If interest rates rise, as most forecasts predict, it will probably be positive for banks provided there is economic growth, says Supervisory Board member Kerstin af Jochnick. But higher interest rates would also hit banks’ borrowers in some sectors https://t.co/xBvmVGbSpi https://t.co/2SzqkZoOn8

Amid global inflationary pressures and risks to growth, we are walking a narrow path as we strive to deliver on our mandate, says Vice-President Luis de Guindos. Normalising monetary policy will require us to move gradually and with caution. Full speech https://t.co/D7vRSIvYC1 https://t.co/J8s4IWB7Xk
Occasional Paper: Costs of retail payments – an overview of recent national studies in Europe https://t.co/c8z82YYs82
Working Paper: The rise in the cross-sectoral dispersion of earnings expectations during COVID-19 https://t.co/GmEzsnBB1d
Account of the monetary policy meeting of the Governing Council of the ECB on 13-14 April 2022 https://t.co/H3CppPtFMR

Enria: We reviewed booking and risk management practices of incoming banks and found that they do not yet have full control over their balance sheets

2/2

🧵 Banks that relocated business from the UK to the EU following Brexit must have adequate local governance and risk management capabilities, says Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria in his latest contribution to The Supervision Blog https://t.co/J1u0DB5OVb

1/2 https://t.co/kXFOhGGQig

So far, the financial system has withstood the challenges of the pandemic and the war in Ukraine, but financial stability cannot be taken for granted, says Klaas Knot, @FinStbBoard Chair and @DNB_NL President. Read more in the Supervision Newsletter https://t.co/f8jI9lQmc8 https://t.co/SIFEw6uIRR

We’re starting a traineeship programme for Ukrainians!

Apply if you’re a Ukrainian citizen and a recent graduate, young professional or a PhD student.

You’ll gain professional experience, benefit from mentoring and receive a monthly grant.

Learn more https://t.co/E3HEyAPs7n https://t.co/1ez5dOYgxr

We’ve extended the deadline for applications to the ECB Scholarship for Women until 1 June!
 
The programme is open to women doing a master’s degree in economics, statistics, engineering or computing and offers grants of €10,000.
 
Find out more https://t.co/U0JWSmHU8b https://t.co/8PFS4YxgeH
Euro area monthly balance of payments (March 2022) https://t.co/MvJ617JciK

Congratulations to our home town team @Eintracht Frankfurt on winning the @EuropaLeague football championship!

A well-deserved victory!

#SGEuropa #SGE #UELfinal 

🎥 by Nicolas Rispal https://t.co/DqnK8vd1GE

What does Klaas Knot, @FinStbBoard Chair and @DNB_NL President, have to say about financial stability? How did supervisors respond to the war in Ukraine? And what can smaller banks do to strengthen their governance? Read more in the Supervision Newsletter https://t.co/f8jI9lQmc8 https://t.co/V2bG6ofif0

The prospect of interest rate normalisation is positive for banks as it increases interest margins and can help profitability, says Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria. It can also have a negative impact on credit quality, but should be positive overall https://t.co/JVEkyym6S8 https://t.co/AOX6BPBlpk

We’re showing our colours on International Day Against Homophobia, Transphobia and Biphobia 🏳️‍🌈
 
Thank you to our Rainbow Network for the pins!
 
#IDAHOBIT https://t.co/ruWlQ15uKs

Enria: We need to foster greater cross-border integration of our banking market. Banks need to view the banking union as a truly domestic market upon which they can build their global activity

3/3

Enria: Of the banking union’s three elements, European banking supervision is fully operational, and as progress is being made with the crisis management framework the deposit insurance scheme will be established

2/3

🧵 We need a unitary framework to complete the banking union, says Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria. Only by looking at its different elements taken together will we be able to achieve progress https://t.co/WZDJjTSus4

1/3 https://t.co/EjUHRzSoHx
Watch again: Chief Economist Philip R. Lane on the fundamental role that a possible digital euro could have https://t.co/uWJI2lOLeq
Watch again: Executive Board member Fabio Panetta on how the digital euro could work together with existing means of payment https://t.co/5ZBXhPN9w1

Did you miss Executive Board member Fabio Panetta and Chief Economist Philip R. Lane discussing the  digital euro at National College of Ireland @NCIRL?

Watch the discussion here 
https://t.co/ANVG5hwViA https://t.co/Id8q3yNhxt

Panetta: For a digital euro to be designed and adopted successfully, it must be a collective endeavour. 
So we are stepping up our engagement with European institutions, banks, payment companies, merchants and society at large

5/5

Panetta: A digital euro would allow us to protect our strategic autonomy while remaining open in a world where technology and dependencies are increasingly being weaponised. And it would enable innovative payment solutions to be quickly scaled up to cover the entire euro area
4/5

Panetta: Crypto-assets are too risky to act as a reliable means of payment. 
They behave like speculative assets and raise multiple public policy and financial stability concerns. Anyone investing in cryptos must be prepared to lose all their investment

3/5

Panetta: A digital euro would offer the possibility for everyone to use public money for digital payments.
“Pay anywhere, pay easily, pay safely” corresponds to what potential users expect from a digital euro

2/5

🧵 A digital euro will allow public money to continue to anchor the stability of the payments system and contribute to its efficiency, says Executive Board member Fabio Panetta at National College of Ireland @NCIRL
https://t.co/IHKiTMZ1Je

1/5 https://t.co/MhyEf7KH6t

Watch live from 10:20 CET: Executive Board member Fabio Panetta and Chief Economist Philip R. Lane speak about a digital euro with Eurogroup President @Paschald, Commissioner @McGuinnessEU and Senator @malcolmbyrne at National College of Ireland @NCIRL

https://t.co/mAevrd5jvm https://t.co/wUIcyHYtf8

Applications for the ECB Scholarship for Women are open until 25 May.
 
“You are good enough!" That's the message from Marina, our current scholarship participant, to all women thinking about applying ⬇️
 
Find out more https://t.co/U0JWSmHU8b https://t.co/OgWjdbJthC

Why is it important for central banks to communicate and be transparent? How can this help to increase trust in what we do?
Find out on #TheECBPodcast with communications experts @GabrielGlockler and @Siria_Angino and our host @KatieRanger_ https://t.co/YJllIPaCvo https://t.co/cx4q6Cw8ow

Any guesses what this photo’s about?

It’s the new episode of #TheECBPodcast, out tomorrow morning!

Spoiler: we’ll be talking reggae, Spider-Man and movie scenes 👀

So, watch out! And catch it on our website and podcast platforms https://t.co/YJllIPaCvo https://t.co/rPsakFa3bq
Working Paper: State-owned banks and international shock transmission https://t.co/7dlwOIaz7U
Working Paper: The digital economy, privacy, and CBDC https://t.co/enrtxFK1tn

Diversity is important to us. As an employer, we want to foster a work environment that’s inclusive in all aspects, including nationality.
 
Our Annual Report now includes data on the different nationalities of ECB staff. Find out more in Section 11.4 https://t.co/KP95lfHcPl https://t.co/t3jFdcJYjX

Enria: Greek banks have made impressive progress in terms of non-performing loans. They can see the finish line now and are close to reaching the same level as their European peers, but they need to continue to work on this

3/3

Enria: We have better policies and better practices to deal with non-performing loans. Banks’ internal controls have been strengthened. We will also assess banks’ capital trajectories and their plans to pay dividends but we are not planning a “one-size-fits-all” restriction 

2/3

🧵 Credit risk remains a major area of attention for banks, Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria tells @ertofficial_. We are also very much focused on IT, cyber and climate change risks. The war in Ukraine has made them even more topical https://t.co/RzNngr5uro 

1/3 https://t.co/dCy8Lfpy7q

After two years of online meetings, the Supervisory Board finally met again in person today! The meeting in Athens was a great opportunity to further strengthen collaboration across Europe. Find out more about European banking supervision https://t.co/8ufLlMabmg https://t.co/RcB0vpz7cA

Congratulations to the 24 teams short-listed for this year’s #EUDatathon!

They now have until 26 June to develop their app ideas into full proposals. 12 teams will then be chosen to go on to the final stage in October https://t.co/fustmreep6 https://t.co/93Ek9Llc4n
Occasional Paper: An empirical study of securitisations of non-performing loans https://t.co/1vIjUK2sns
Euro area securities issues statistics (March 2022) https://t.co/8GC1AtPGad

Global excess demand is feeding into underlying price pressures even in countries with domestic slack, says Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel. The globalisation of inflation makes it even more important to keep inflation expectations firmly anchored 
https://t.co/D8eR6UDSpA https://t.co/IVikuIcvmw

Lagarde: Whatever the circumstances, we have remained committed to the euro and to our mandate, and we have shown the necessary degree of flexibility. We have travelled a difficult road and still face many challenges. But I am confident that we will overcome them

2/2

🧵 Over the last decade Europe has faced repeated shocks, says President @Lagarde at @BankaSlovenije. But each of these shocks has left us stronger, because we have acted decisively to close the gaps they have revealed https://t.co/yuvBB2cBkd

1/2
Register now and watch live from 19:30 CET: Vice-President Luis de Guindos speaks at @iesebschool about the economic outlook and financial stability https://t.co/dfciSWDnrY
Euro money market statistics (2nd maintenance period 2022) https://t.co/uxLIWZFPdb

Interest rates on new housing loans in the euro area rose to 1.47% on average in March. This is the sharpest month-on-month increase since 2011. 

Read our press release for more statistics on this topic https://t.co/TeObY8BWuQ https://t.co/f3PYBvKvZN

Happy Europe Day! 🇪🇺🎉

On this day in 1950, the Schuman Declaration was signed. Based on the principles of peace and solidarity, it heralded the first step towards European integration.

Join us in celebrating Europe and what unites us! https://t.co/3YmDrKSN7G

This #EuropeDay is different.

Today is the anniversary of the Schuman Declaration, which paved the way for the creation of the EU.

This year we also stand in solidarity with our Ukrainian neighbours as they defend themselves against Russia’s aggression.

We must work for peace. https://t.co/Dhk7kNlAan

Lagarde: Adjustments to our key interest rates will be gradual and will take place some time after the end of net asset purchases. My expectation is that these purchases should be concluded early in the third quarter

3/3

Lagarde: Our task is to maintain price stability in the euro area over the medium term. Three general principles will guide us:
1⃣Optionality to respond to different scenarios
2⃣Gradualism to allow us to act prudently
3⃣Flexibility to ensure even monetary policy transmission

2/3

🧵Russia’s war in Ukraine is first and foremost a human tragedy, President @Lagarde tells @Delo. It is also weighing on growth and boosting inflation. At the same time, the reopening of the economy after the pandemic is supporting economic activity https://t.co/3hP9yjKoOJ
 
1/3 https://t.co/bdjK88cgzg
⚡️ Missed our live Twitter Q&A with Executive Board member @FrankElderson? Catch up here! #AskECB https://t.co/MizL051Dpu
Letter from the ECB President to Mr Eugen Jurzyca, MEP, on the euro https://t.co/atxvHAGvpI
Letter from the ECB President to Mr Marco Zanni, Mr Valentino Grant and Mr Antonio Maria Rinaldi, MEPs, on monetary policy https://t.co/sIkyK8U9IL (EN) https://t.co/uPeTBWb3rc (IT)

The green transition will help lower energy prices in the long run, @Isabel_Schnabel tells @MyStephanomics. 
During the transition, monetary policy may not be able to look through rising energy prices if they pose a threat to price stability. 

The podcast https://t.co/AMIzShDkZy https://t.co/vKrtsNVZtM
